title: Psalms Chapter 147 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 147 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 147 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 147.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147:1, why should we praise the LORD?
options: Because it is good to sing praises unto our God
Because He created the heavens and the earth
Because He gives us wealth and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is good to sing praises unto our God
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:1 states that it is good to sing praises unto our God, and that praise is pleasant and comely.

questions.question: Who does the LORD gather together, according to Psalms 147:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The outcasts of Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:2 says the LORD gathers together the outcasts of Israel.

questions.question: What does the LORD do to the broken in heart as per Psalms 147:3?
options: He healeth them and bindeth up their wounds
He hides them from their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He healeth them and bindeth up their wounds
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:3 explains that God heals the broken in heart and binds up their wounds.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147:4, what does God do concerning the stars?
options: He telleth their number and calleth them all by their names
He created only a few stars
He hides the stars in the clouds
He moves the stars with His hand
questions.correctAnswer: He telleth their number and calleth them all by their names
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:4 states God tells the number of the stars and calls them all by their names.

questions.question: What is said about the LORD’s understanding in Psalms 147:5?
options: His understanding is equal to man’s
questions.correctAnswer: His understanding is infinite
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:5 declares that the LORD’s understanding is infinite.

questions.question: Who does the LORD lift up and who does He cast down according to Psalms 147:6?
options: He lifteth up the meek and casteth the wicked down to the ground
He lifteth up the proud and casteth the poor down
He lifteth up the rich and casteth the poor down
He lifteth up the strong and casteth the weak down
questions.correctAnswer: He lifteth up the meek and casteth the wicked down to the ground
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:6 clearly states that the LORD lifteth up the meek and casteth the wicked down.

questions.question: What instrument is mentioned for singing praises to the LORD in Psalms 147:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Harp
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:7 instructs to sing praise upon the harp unto our God.

questions.question: Which of the following does God prepare for the earth according to Psalms 147:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Rain
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:8 mentions that God prepareth rain for the earth.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147:10, in what does God NOT take delight?
questions.correctAnswer: The strength of the horse
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:10 states the LORD delighteth not in the strength of the horse.

questions.question: Who does the LORD take pleasure in, according to Psalms 147:11?
options: Them that fear him and hope in his mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Them that fear him and hope in his mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:11 says the LORD taketh pleasure in those that fear him and hope in his mercy.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 147:12 commands Jerusalem to praise God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:12 instructs Jerusalem to praise the LORD and Zion to praise their God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147:13, what has God strengthened in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: The bars of thy gates
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:13 states that God hath strengthened the bars of Jerusalem’s gates.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 147:15 says God's word runs very slowly on the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:15 says God's word runneth very swiftly upon the earth.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 147:16: 'He giveth snow like ______: he scattereth the hoarfrost like ashes.'
questions.correctAnswer: wool
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:16 uses the simile 'snow like wool' to describe snow.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 147:20 says God has dealt with all nations the same way He has dealt with Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:20 states that God hath not dealt so with any nation as with Israel.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 147 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 147 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 147, what biblical truth would you share about God's care in difficult times?
options: God heals the broken in heart and binds up their wounds
God prefers the strong and mighty over the weak
God ignores those who are suffering
God only helps those who are wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: God heals the broken in heart and binds up their wounds
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:3 teaches that God heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds, showing His care and comfort for believers in trials. This truth is supported by verses 6 and 11, where God lifts up the meek and takes pleasure in those who fear Him.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 teach us about humility and contentment in our relationship with God?
options: The LORD lifts up the meek and casts down the wicked
The LORD delights in the strength of horses and men
God favors those with many possessions
God ignores the humble and rewards the proud
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD lifts up the meek and casts down the wicked
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows God's favor toward the meek, encouraging humility. Verses 10 and 11 emphasize that God does not delight in human strength but in those who fear Him and hope in His mercy, teaching contentment and reverence.

questions.question: In what way does Psalms 147 encourage thankfulness and worship in daily life?
options: Sing unto the LORD with thanksgiving and praise upon the harp
Pray only in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Sing unto the LORD with thanksgiving and praise upon the harp
questions.explanation: Verse 7 instructs believers to sing to the LORD with thanksgiving and praise, highlighting the importance of regular worship and gratitude in our spiritual discipline, supported by verses 1 and 12.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear and anxiety. Based on Psalms 147, what truth about God's power and understanding can bring reassurance?
options: Great is our Lord, of great power, and His understanding is infinite
God is limited and does not know all things
God is distant and uninterested in human affairs
God only helps when He chooses arbitrarily
questions.correctAnswer: Great is our Lord, of great power, and His understanding is infinite
questions.explanation: Verse 5 affirms God's greatness, power, and infinite understanding, assuring believers that God is fully capable of caring for them with perfect wisdom and strength, also reflected in verses 4 and 15.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 instruct believers about trusting God's provision in daily work and stewardship?
options: God gives food to the beasts and young ravens that cry
Hard work alone guarantees success without God's help
God ignores the needs of His creation
We should rely only on our own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God gives food to the beasts and young ravens that cry
questions.explanation: Verse 9 illustrates God's provision even for animals, teaching believers to trust in God's care for all needs, encouraging a faithful and grateful attitude in work and stewardship, supported by verses 8 and 14.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 reveal about God's attitude toward those who fear Him and hope in His mercy?
options: The LORD takes pleasure in them
They are less favored than the proud
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD takes pleasure in them
questions.explanation: Verse 11 clearly states that God delights in those who fear Him and hope in His mercy, encouraging believers to cultivate reverence and trust in God's compassion, also supported by verses 6 and 3.

questions.question: A believer is seeking encouragement to persevere through trials. According to Psalms 147, what aspect of God's word can strengthen their faith?
options: God's word runs swiftly and accomplishes His command
God's word is slow and uncertain
God's word is only for the ancient times
God does not communicate with His people
questions.correctAnswer: God's word runs swiftly and accomplishes His command
questions.explanation: Verse 15 emphasizes the power and speed of God's word, affirming that His promises and commands are effective, which encourages believers to trust and persevere, also seen in verses 19 and 20.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 147 teaches that God delights most in human strength and physical power.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clarifies that God does not delight in the strength of horses or the legs of a man, indicating that human power is not the basis of God's pleasure, but rather reverence and hope as in verse 11.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 147, God’s blessings bring peace and provision to His people’s homes and land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 14 describe how God strengthens Jerusalem’s gates and fills the land with the finest wheat, symbolizing peace and provision for His people, encouraging believers to trust in His care.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 teach us about the importance of sharing God’s word with others?
options: He shows His word to Jacob and His statutes to Israel
God’s word is only for the chosen few and should be kept secret
God’s word is outdated and irrelevant
People do not need to know God’s judgments
questions.correctAnswer: He shows His word to Jacob and His statutes to Israel
questions.explanation: Verse 19 highlights God's revealing of His word and statutes to His people, encouraging believers to know, live by, and share God's truth, which is further emphasized in verse 20.

questions.question: A believer wants to cultivate a spirit of gratitude and praise. Based on Psalms 147, what practical step should they take?
options: Praise the LORD with singing and thanksgiving
Praise God silently without any expression
questions.correctAnswer: Praise the LORD with singing and thanksgiving
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 7 instruct believers to sing praises to God and do so with thanksgiving, fostering a grateful heart and regular worship in daily life.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 encourage believers to handle personal weaknesses and trials?
options: God heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds
Trials are a punishment with no hope
questions.correctAnswer: God heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds
questions.explanation: Verse 3 offers hope by affirming God’s healing for the broken in heart, encouraging believers to rely on God's compassion and care during hardships, supported by verses 6 and 11.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Praise the LORD, O _____; praise thy God, O Zion."
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verse 12 calls for Jerusalem and Zion to praise God, highlighting the importance of communal worship and devotion among God's people.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 teach about God's control over nature and its implications for our trust in Him?
options: God covers the heavens with clouds and prepares rain for the earth
God is unaware of natural events
questions.correctAnswer: God covers the heavens with clouds and prepares rain for the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 8 shows God’s sovereignty over nature, providing for the earth and its inhabitants, encouraging believers to trust in His providential care, supported by verses 16-18.

questions.question: How can Psalms 147 guide a believer in their attitude towards God's judgments and laws?
options: God’s judgments are known uniquely to Israel and not dealt with other nations
All nations equally understand God’s judgments
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgments are known uniquely to Israel and not dealt with other nations
questions.explanation: Verse 20 reveals that God’s judgments and laws are specially revealed to Israel, encouraging believers to honor and obey God's statutes, as seen in verses 19 and 15.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 147 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 147.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 147:1 with the phrases 'good to sing praises' and 'pleasant; and praise is comely'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:1 uses synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, repeating similar ideas about praise to emphasize its goodness and pleasantness.

questions.question: In Psalms 147:2, the LORD is described as building up Jerusalem and gathering whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The outcasts of Israel
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states the LORD gathers the outcasts of Israel, highlighting God's restorative work for his people.

questions.question: What does the LORD do for the brokenhearted according to Psalms 147:3?
options: He healeth and bindeth up their wounds
questions.correctAnswer: He healeth and bindeth up their wounds
questions.explanation: The verse depicts God's compassionate healing, emphasizing His role as a comforter and healer of emotional and spiritual brokenness.

questions.question: How is God's knowledge of the stars described in Psalms 147:4, and what theological implication does this have?
options: He numbers and names all the stars, showing His sovereign and intimate knowledge of creation
He creates stars only for Israel's benefit
He ignores the stars, focusing on humans
He uses stars to punish the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He numbers and names all the stars, showing His sovereign and intimate knowledge of creation
questions.explanation: The verse portrays God's infinite understanding and sovereignty by highlighting His control over the cosmos, symbolizing omniscience.

questions.question: Psalms 147:5 says, 'Great is our Lord, and of great power: his understanding is infinite.' How does this relate to the theme of divine omnipotence in the Old Testament?
options: It affirms God's limitless power and wisdom, consistent with themes in Isaiah and Job
It limits God's power to only creation
It compares God to earthly kings
It denies God's involvement in human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's limitless power and wisdom, consistent with themes in Isaiah and Job
questions.explanation: The verse echoes Old Testament themes where God's infinite wisdom and power surpass human understanding, as seen in Isaiah 40 and Job 38.

questions.question: What is the contrast presented between the meek and the wicked in Psalms 147:6?
options: The LORD lifts up the meek but casts the wicked down to the ground
The meek are ignored and the wicked are exalted
Both meek and wicked receive equal judgment
The meek are punished and the wicked rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD lifts up the meek but casts the wicked down to the ground
questions.explanation: This verse highlights a key biblical theme of divine justice, showing God's favor toward humility and judgment against wickedness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 147:7, singing praise with thanksgiving to God is commanded only during the festival of Tabernacles.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse encourages continual praise and thanksgiving to God, not limited to a specific festival, reflecting a general call to worship.

questions.question: Which natural phenomena are attributed to God's providence in Psalms 147:8?
options: Covering the heaven with clouds, preparing rain, and making grass grow on mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Covering the heaven with clouds, preparing rain, and making grass grow on mountains
questions.explanation: The verse poetically describes God's control over weather and nature, underscoring His sustaining power over life.

questions.question: Psalms 147:9 highlights God's provision for animals. Which animals are specifically mentioned?
questions.correctAnswer: Beasts and young ravens
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes God's care for all creatures, including beasts and ravens, illustrating divine providence beyond humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147:10, what does God not take delight in?
options: The strength of the horse and the legs of a man
questions.correctAnswer: The strength of the horse and the legs of a man
questions.explanation: The verse rejects reliance on human or military strength, emphasizing God's preference for those who fear Him instead.

questions.question: In Psalms 147:11, in whom does the LORD take pleasure?
options: Those who fear Him and hope in His mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Those who fear Him and hope in His mercy
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the importance of reverence and trust in God’s mercy as the basis for divine favor.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147:14 indicate God does for Jerusalem's borders?
options: Makes peace and fills with the finest wheat
questions.correctAnswer: Makes peace and fills with the finest wheat
questions.explanation: The verse expresses God's blessing in both security (peace) and provision (fine wheat), reflecting covenantal blessings.

questions.question: How is God's word described in Psalms 147:15 and 18 in terms of its action on earth?
options: It runs swiftly and melts ice through wind
questions.correctAnswer: It runs swiftly and melts ice through wind
questions.explanation: These verses illustrate the powerful and dynamic nature of God's word in controlling natural forces.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147:16-17, what imagery is used to describe snow and ice, and what does it signify about God's control over nature?
options: Snow like wool and ice like morsels, signifying God's sovereign power over cold elements
Snow like fire and ice like water, symbolizing chaos
Snow like dust and ice like stones, indicating judgment
Snow and ice are not mentioned
questions.correctAnswer: Snow like wool and ice like morsels, signifying God's sovereign power over cold elements
questions.explanation: The vivid imagery emphasizes God's authority over all natural phenomena, including harsh winter elements.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 147:20 states that all nations know God's statutes and judgments just as Israel does.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that no other nation has been dealt with as Israel nor have they known God's judgments as Israel has.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 147 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 147 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147, what is the nature of God's understanding?
questions.correctAnswer: Infinite and great
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:5 states that God’s understanding is infinite, emphasizing His omniscience and wisdom. This is consistent with Job 12:13, Isaiah 40:28, Romans 11:33, and 1 John 3:20 which affirm God's infinite wisdom and knowledge.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 teach about God's care for the brokenhearted?
options: He heals and binds up their wounds
He leaves them to heal on their own
questions.correctAnswer: He heals and binds up their wounds
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:3 reveals God’s compassionate nature as He heals the broken in heart and binds up their wounds. Scripture such as Isaiah 61:1, Matthew 11:28, Psalm 34:18, and Revelation 21:4 also affirm God's tender care for the brokenhearted.

questions.question: What does the Psalm say about God's relationship with the meek and the wicked?
options: He lifts up the meek and casts down the wicked
He favors the wicked over the meek
He ignores both meek and wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He lifts up the meek and casts down the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:6 teaches that the LORD lifts up the meek and casts down the wicked, highlighting God's justice and mercy. This aligns with passages like Matthew 5:5, James 4:6, Proverbs 3:34, and 1 Peter 5:5.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 describe God's knowledge of the stars?
options: He counts and names all the stars
He created only a few stars
He does not care about the stars
The stars are beyond His knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: He counts and names all the stars
questions.explanation: According to Psalms 147:4, God tells the number of the stars and calls them by name, demonstrating His sovereignty over creation. This is supported by Isaiah 40:26, Jeremiah 33:22, Hebrews 11:12, and Job 38:7.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 say about God's pleasure in human strength or horses?
options: He delights in horses and strong men
He takes no pleasure in the strength of horses or legs of men
He prefers human strength over faith
He values military power above all
questions.correctAnswer: He takes no pleasure in the strength of horses or legs of men
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:10 states that God does not delight in the strength of the horse nor in the legs of a man, emphasizing that true security and favor come from fearing God rather than human might. This theme is echoed in Psalm 20:7, Isaiah 31:1, Jeremiah 17:5, and Zechariah 4:6.

questions.question: Who does the LORD take pleasure in, according to Psalms 147?
options: Those who fear Him and hope in His mercy
Those who show the greatest strength
questions.correctAnswer: Those who fear Him and hope in His mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:11 reveals that God takes pleasure in those who fear Him and hope in His mercy, highlighting the importance of reverence and trust in God's grace. This is consistent with Exodus 20:20, Proverbs 9:10, Psalm 103:13, and Lamentations 3:22-23.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 say about God's provision for animals?
options: He gives food to beasts and ravens
He only cares for domesticated animals
questions.correctAnswer: He gives food to beasts and ravens
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:9 states that God gives food to the beast and to the young ravens which cry, demonstrating His providential care for all creation. This care is echoed in Matthew 6:26, Luke 12:24, Job 38:41, and Psalm 104:14-15.

questions.question: According to Psalms 147, what is God's action concerning Jerusalem?
options: He builds it up and gathers the outcasts of Israel
He destroys it for their sins
He ignores the city and its people
questions.correctAnswer: He builds it up and gathers the outcasts of Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:2 teaches that the LORD builds up Jerusalem and gathers the outcasts of Israel, reflecting His redemptive work and restoration of His people. This is reflected in Isaiah 61:4, Ezra 1:2, Nehemiah 2:17, and Jeremiah 30:18.

questions.question: What natural phenomena does Psalms 147 attribute to God's command?
questions.correctAnswer: Rain, snow, hoarfrost, and ice
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:8, 16-17 describe God covering the heavens with clouds, preparing rain, giving snow like wool, scattering hoarfrost, and casting forth ice, illustrating His sovereign control over creation’s elements. This is consistent with Job 37:6-10, Isaiah 55:10, Matthew 5:45, and Jeremiah 10:13.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 describe the speed of God's word?
options: It runs very swiftly upon the earth
questions.correctAnswer: It runs very swiftly upon the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:15 states that God’s word runs swiftly upon the earth, indicating the power and effectiveness of God’s commands. This is echoed in Isaiah 55:11, Hebrews 4:12, Matthew 24:35, and 1 Thessalonians 2:13.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 say about God's statutes and judgments?
options: He shows them to Jacob and Israel, but not to other nations
He reveals them equally to all nations
He hides them from His people
questions.correctAnswer: He shows them to Jacob and Israel, but not to other nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:19-20 reveal that God has shown His statutes and judgments to Jacob and Israel but has not dealt so with any other nation, emphasizing the special covenant relationship. This is consistent with Exodus 19:5-6, Deuteronomy 7:6, Romans 9:4, and John 1:17.

questions.question: What is the significance of praising God in Psalms 147?
options: It is good, pleasant, and comely to sing praises unto God
It is only for priests and kings
questions.correctAnswer: It is good, pleasant, and comely to sing praises unto God
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:1 encourages praise as good, pleasant, and fitting, highlighting worship as a central response to God’s nature. This aligns with Psalm 100:1-2, Hebrews 13:15, Psalm 95:1-2, and Ephesians 5:19.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 describe God's provision of peace and abundance to Jerusalem?
options: He makes peace in her borders and fills her with the finest wheat
questions.correctAnswer: He makes peace in her borders and fills her with the finest wheat
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:14 explains God’s blessing of peace and provision of the finest wheat to Jerusalem, indicating His role as protector and provider. Related passages include Isaiah 32:17, Jeremiah 31:12, John 14:27, and Philippians 4:7.

questions.question: What does Psalms 147 say about God’s action in strengthening Jerusalem’s gates and blessing her children?
options: He strengthens the gates and blesses the children within
He weakens the gates and curses the children
questions.correctAnswer: He strengthens the gates and blesses the children within
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:13 indicates God’s protective and blessing role over Jerusalem's defenses and inhabitants, showing His care for the city's security and future generations. Similar ideas are found in Nehemiah 2:17, Psalm 127:1, Isaiah 54:13, and Deuteronomy 33:7.

questions.question: How does Psalms 147 describe God's power over cold and ice?
options: He casts ice like morsels and causes cold before which none can stand
He is powerless over winter elements
He forbids cold and ice entirely
questions.correctAnswer: He casts ice like morsels and causes cold before which none can stand
questions.explanation: Psalms 147:17 describes God’s sovereignty over cold as He casts forth ice and causes intense cold, illustrating His control over nature. This correlates with Job 37:10-13, Jeremiah 18:14, Nahum 1:3, and Psalm 74:17.
